newsitem.title: USA: IMM currency futures close narrowly mixed.
newsitem.headline: IMM currency futures close narrowly mixed.

text.p: IMM currency futures closed narrowly mixed in driftless dollar trade, as traders and dealers weighed the possibility of intervention by foreign central banks, analysts said.
"Everyone is cautious," Michael Malpede, senior currency analyst at Refco Inc, said. "There doesn's seem to be much interest in pushing the dollar higher."

Such concerns kept September marks and Swiss francs above the contract lows that both currencies set overnight. September marks fell to $0.5355 on GLOBEX, below support of $0.5371, or 1.8730 spot, and Swiss francs eased to $0.6547.
Speculation the Bundesbank may intervene against the dollar lingered in the market on Monday morning after heavy overseas selling on Sunday evening, analysts said.
"The talk is sketchy, but the Bundesbank doesn't have a lot of options right now," Malpede said.
He dismissed the chance that the Bundesbank could open the door to higher short-term interest rates, since the move could act as a further drag on Germany's economy.
Malpede also noted that cash marks performed well against several European currencies.
Regarding concerns about Japanese intervention, Malpede said there are "general feelings the Bank of Japan may want to step in at the 119.00 to 120.00 area."
The 119.00 to 120.00 spot yen area corresponds to $0.008454 to $0.008384 in September yen, traders said.
September yen managed to hold gains above the $0.008500 level late in the session. Resistance is seen at last Friday's high of $0.008540.

At the close, September yen rose $0.000004 to $0.008502, marks were off $0.0009 to $0.5371, Swiss francs were $0.0003 higher to $0.6584, sterling was down $0.0022 to $1.6262, Canadian dollars gained $0.0009 to $0.7271, Australian dollars were up $0.0029 to $0.7421, and Mexican pesos rose $0.000650 to $0.125875.
